{{Distinguish|Business nationalism}} {{Wiktionary|corporate nationalism}} {{Corporatism sidebar}} '''Corporate nationalism''' is a phrase that is used to convey various meanings, including: *A [[political culture]], in which members believe the basic unit of society and the primary concern of the state is the [[corporate group (sociology)|corporate group]] rather than the individual, and that the interests of the corporate group are the same as the interest of the nation. *Corporations should work mainly for the national good, rather than the good of their owners *Corporations should be protected from foreign ownership *Corporations should (may) be nationalized *The state is biased towards corporate interests
==State should deal with corporations rather than individuals==
"Corporate Nationalism" may be used to describe a [[political philosophy]] and [[economic theories|economic theory]] whose adherents are [[corporatism|corporatists]] and believe that the basic unit of the society, be it the family or other [[corporate group (sociology)|corporate group]]s, has the same interests as the [[nation]]. Some therefore believe that the state should deal primarily with "corporations", which may include companies, worker's cooperatives, unions and so on, and allow these units to organize themselves to serve their members as they feel fit.<ref>Wolfgang Streeck & Lane Kenworthy, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Kmr6gBjhRI4C&pg=PA441&lpg=PA441&dq=neocorporatism+schmitter&source=web&ots=N3SHQvThaq&sig=b94xLY4X_pKzuIdtQ2thZonD3Co "Theories and Practices of Neocorporatism"]. Iin Thomas Janoski (ed.) ''The Handbook of Political Sociology'' (Cambridge Univ. Press: 2005), p. 441ff.</ref>
==Corporations should work mainly for the national good== The Christian [[Falange|Falangist]] Party of America espouses this view. They do not reject the right of investors to make profit, but believe they do not have the right to take actions such as moving factories to other countries and thus endangering American workers.<ref>[http://www.falange1.com/faq1.htm ''Frequently Asked Questions''] Christian Falangist Party of America</ref> Also in the USA, the left-wing [[New Alliance Party]] is said to have described Zionism as "Jewish corporate nationalism", although the exact meaning of this presumed slur is not clear.<ref>[http://www.adl.org/special_reports/nap.asp ''A Cult By Any Other Name. The New Alliance Party Dismantled and Reincarnated''] Anti-Defamation League.</ref>
==National corporations should be protected from foreign ownership== Norway has a history of state campaigns to block foreign companies from taking over major Norwegian firms.<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/governmentFilingsNews/idUKL1234466320070412 ''Norway watchdog wary of Kaupthing buying insurer''] Reuters Apr 12, 2007.</ref> In 2005, PepsiCo was rumored to be planning a bid to take over French food group Danone, arousing popular outcry. A former boss of Danone said. "Danone is like Chartres cathedral, and one does not buy the cathedral of Chartres."<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2006/feb/27/france.internationalnews1 ''Battle to preserve identity''] The Guardian 27 February 2006.</ref>
==Corporations should (may) be nationalized==
The phrase may be used to describe national intervention in corporations, including outright nationalization where the state assumes ownership of the corporation. Some see recent US government interventions in the Financial industry, including the effective nationalization of [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]] are seen as a form of corporate nationalism.<ref>[http://www.marketoracle.co.uk/Article5605.html ''It's Always Darkest Before the Dawn...of a Economic Depression''] marketoracle.co.uk. Jul 24, 2008.</ref>
==The state is biased towards corporate interests==
Some libertarians in the USA consider that the end of slavery coincided with the start of a regime "tainted" by aggressive ''corporate nationalism'', or government intervention into the economy.<ref>[http://www.lewrockwell.com/gregory/gregory136.html ''Real World Politics and Radical Libertarianism''] Lew Rockwell.com: anti-state, anti-war, pro-market. April 22, 2007.</ref> In this view, the destruction of chattel slavery preserved and perpetuated "bourgeois" slavery.<ref name=Hummel1996>{{Citation | last = Hummel | first = Jeffrey Rogers | year = 1996 | title = Emancipating slaves, enslaving free men : a history of the American Civil War | isbn = 0-8126-9311-6 | publisher = Open Court | location = Chicago, Ill. }}</ref>
